chapter.title: Knowledge Editor
chapter.para: The Editor allows users to view, modify, create concepts, modify concepts, classify, create versions, export versions, create value sets and modify value sets. This chapter provides an overview of the Editor layout and details on authoring content. Users are able to see changes made by all users in real-time.

There are two roles that a user can have which changes the functionality available: Author and Administrator role. The Administrator role has all the functionality as an Author with the addition of the ability to Release content. The functionality to Release content is present in the navigation bar and is described below.

section.title: Editor Layout
section.para:
The Knowledge Editor is divided into three sections: the task pane, the concept viewer, and the navigation bar (see below). While each of these functions are described in more details in the succeeding sections, a description of each area is provided below:
Task Pane – The Task Pane consists of several tabs that contain the following functionality:
Taxonomy – the Taxonomy tab displays the content in a hierarchical view. It is always the default view when a user logs into Knowledge.
Sets – displays value sets and maps; the user can create, edit and view them here.
Search – the search function enables the user to search for specific descriptions, ids and other values.
Classifier – the user can run the classifier and view results of classification.
QA – data checks can be initiated and results can be viewed.
Export and Versions – users with the appropriate permissions can export content and/or create a version.
Briefcase – is similar to a bookmarks list. Throughout the editor, there are tables that will allow users to add concepts to the Briefcase. Users can then view or modify them here.
Concept Viewer – The Concept Viewer displays details of the concept or item selected in the task pane.
Navigation – The Navigation bar enables fast access to functions e.g. New Concept, Run Classifier, Return to Knowledge Manager page, Modify global display options
Knowledge Editor Layout

section.title: Taxonomy View
section.para: In the Taxonomy view, users can navigate through the concept hierarchy under the taxonomy tree. The Taxonomy also displays the concepts with their parents and their children. Users can traverse the tree by selecting the caret symbol on the left of the tree to display the selected concept's children.

The tree-like structure of the Taxonomy View allows users to navigate content from a "top-down" view – users can navigate up or down in the lineage of the content by selecting the caret symbol on the left. The user can also select to display the inferred or stated view of the content (Knowledge displays the inferred view by default). The inferred view shows the parent-child lineage that is derived by inferences through a set of logical rules and related concepts; the stated view shows the parent-child lineage that is set by the author when creating the concept.

simplesect.title: Status
simplesect.para: In addition, the user can display active only concepts or both active and inactive concepts. Inactive concepts will display in italics. The default is set to display onlyactive concepts. To see both types, change the settings under "Display Options".

simplesect.title: Display Type
simplesect.para: The user has an additional option to display the Fully Qualified Name (FQN) or the Normal Name (NAM) of the concept.

simplesect.title: Refresh the Taxonomy
simplesect.para: The user is also able to force a refresh of the taxonomy by selecting the Refresh button. This is useful when multiple concepts are expanded and the user would like to collapse them all.

simplesect.title: Concept Type – Defined versus Primitive
simplesect.para:
In Knowledge, concepts are defined as either a defined or primitive.
Defined concept
Defined – A concept that is defined is represented by a green circle. A concept is considered defined by unique relationships between its relatives (e.g. siblings and parents)
Primitive – A concept that is primitive is represented by an orange hexagon and signifies that its attributes and parents composing the concept are non-definitive characteristics.

simplesect.title: Linking the Taxonomy View with Search Results
simplesect.para:
In the Knowledge Editor, the user can connect/link the concept selected in the Taxonomy to the Concept Viewer Panel, by default the connection or linkage is set. This means when users select a concept in the taxonomy, the Concept Viewer will display the details of that concept. The same is true if a user selects a result from a search. Linkage can be modified by toggling the linkage icon in the upper left-hand corner of the concept details panel. Linked
Unlinked
If a concept becomes unlinked and users click on a different term to review, a new Concept View Panel will open. A maximum of two concept viewers can be opened. If two Concept Viewer Panels are already open and both concept viewers are linked, the system will choose to display the new concept selected on one of the existing panels. If both concept viewers are unlinked the concept viewers will not display the concept information of the selected concept.

section.title: Sets
section.para: The Sets tab allows a user to create, and modify value sets, and map sets. Value sets are a collection of concepts that is used for a specific purpose (e.g. Wound Color Value Set would contain the concepts needed to describe the color of a wound by a clinician). A map set is a mapping between one terminology and another (e.g. SNOMED CT to LOINC mapping).

section.title: Creating a Value Set
section.para: A value set is also known as a simple assemblage or refset and contains a collection of concepts used for a particular purpose determined by its author. For example: The SNOMED CT Value Set – Lateralizable body structure reference set is a user defined simple assemblage (or value set) created for values used to record the measurement site of a patients heart rate, where the values could be finger, ear lobe, and wrist. There are two ways to create a new value set: by selecting "Create Refset" under the Shortcuts navigation menu, or by selecting the "New" button under the Sets tab in the Authoring viewing pane. On the Create New Value Set page, fill out the information needed, check the box for "This concept is a Value Set," and select "Create". After the refset is created, you will see the ability to add concept members on the left pane.

simplesect.title: Adding Members to a Value Set
simplesect.para: To add members to a value set, select the "Edit" link when viewing the value set's details. This will take you into an edit view where concepts can be added, removed, or imported.
Select "Add Member" to find concepts to add, select the remove icon to remove them, and select the add to briefcase icon to add any of them to your briefcase.
When you are ready to save the members list, select "Compare Sync" to review your changes.
If there are any conflicts, the table will display the information to help you decide how to sync the new data into the refset.

simplesect.title: Removing Value Set Members
simplesect.para: To remove members from a refset, select the "Edit Members" button when viewing the refset details. This will take you to Edit Mode, where you can remove members from the table by selecting the "X" icon. The system will display your selection in the table "Value Set membership Changes" for review. Press Save to confirm your updates.

section.title: Creating a Map Set
section.para: A map set associates codes that have the same or similar meaning in one system with another. For example, SNOMED CT's code for "Vital signs monitoring" can be mapped to LOINC's "Vital signs with method details panel" and "Vital signs with smoking status and pain scale [VSP]".
To create a map set, go to the Sets tab in the left panel, make sure that "View Group" is set to "Map Set" and select New to open the form.
There are 3 tabs in the Concept Viewer panel for the user to fill out: Definition, Item Fields, and Business Rules.

listitem.para: Definition - Enter the name, purpose, and any additional information that users may need for the new map set. You can add more fields such as source code version by selecting the "Add More Fields" button on the left.

Item Fields - These are column headers to display when you view the map sets. Source description, target description, and equivalence type are selected by default, but you may add more fields or rearrange the order the columns display by selecting the "Add More Fields to Map Set Items" button.
Business Rules - This is a free text comment box for additional information that users may find useful, such as the use case and guidance on when to use the map set.

section.para: After entering all relevant information, press the save button at the top of the panel. The new map set sould appear in the left panel's Map Sets table. If you do not see it there, press the Refresh button.

section.title: Search
section.para:
Search can be performed in the Authoring interface through keywords and Lucene query syntax. Knowledge has implemented Lucene, an open-source full-text search library, as one of its search engines. To begin searching, select the “Search” tab on the left panel, then fill in the fields as needed. Both Simple Search and Advanced Search use Lucene. For more details on the Lucene search syntax refer to the Lucene tutorial
Simple Search – searches for descriptions that matches the search phrase
Advanced Search – refines the search parameters further searching for terminology id, description types (fully qualified name, name, and definition)

section.title: Simple Search
section.para: Terminologies can be searched by keywords under the Search tab in the task pane. Type in keywords in the “Search Text” field, then select the “Search” button to start the search, .

Simple search allows users to search for the keywords
typed in the search box. Selecting the search button will return all descriptions that match. Keywords used in simple search are single terms or phrases. A Single Term is a single word such as "test" or "hello". A Phrase is a group of words surrounded by double quotes such as "hello dolly". If a group of words without double quotes are used such as hello goodbye, then the results will display results that contain either “hello” or “goodbye”. Multiple terms can be combined with Boolean operators to form a more complex query. Review Lucene query keyword matchingfor more advanced search syntax.

section.title: Advanced Search
section.para: Search results can be filtered by using the Advanced Search section, see . There are 4 options in the Advanced Search section:

listitem.para: Search In – This option narrows the search for Search Text to concept Descriptions, Semantics, or Identifiers. When Descriptions is selected the search will search-in the Descriptions of a concept. A search in Semantics searches the properties of a concept, and a search in Identifiers searches the alphanumeric IDs of a concept such as an SCTID or LOINC code.
Page size – Select the number of results to display at a time.

Description Type – The sytem restricts the search to a particular description type, such as Fully Qualified Name (FQN), a Regular Name, a Definition if selected. When All Types is selected the search will be performed on FQN,Regular Name and Definition.
CSV Export – When selected, the search results table will export the results table in CSV format.

section.para: Select the search button in order to update the results when advanced options are changed.

section.title: Classifier
section.para: The Knowledge Editor integrates a high performance Classifier called SnoRocket https://aehrc.com/snorocket/which supports OWL EL++ and Concrete Domains. The classifier evaluates the stated relationships based on Description Logics upon which the terminology is defined and generates the inferred relationships for each concept. The Knowledge Editor displays stated and inferred views of the concept in the concept viewer pane and the Taxonomy displays stated and inferred is-a relationships based on the Taxonomy display options.

section.title: Run the Classifier
section.para: There are two areas in the Knowledge Editor interface to initiate classification: the navigation menu Short Cuts and the Classifier tab, .

The first classification will evaluate all concepts in the environment, subsequent classifications will evaluate only modified concepts. The first classification duration will be less than 15 minutes, and subsequent classifications will be less than 10 minutes. A classification has three possible status values: Running, Done, and Failed.
To start classification select the Run Classifier button. An entry will be added to the Classifier Run List. The user can select the Refresh Run List to force an update of the run list table.

section.title: View Classifier Results
section.para: When the classifier has completed, the status will change from Running to Done. A user may view classification results by selecting an entry in the Classifier Run List. The results of classification are displayed on the right in Classifier Details, .

The classifier details will provide a summary and details of:
Affected concepts - this is a list of concepts are classification.
Equivalent sets – shows any defined concepts that have identical relationships.
Orphaned concepts – are concepts that are not defined correctly and must be corrected.
Cycles – the classifier finds cycles that would be difficult to find just by looking at the definition of a concept e.g. A ->B ->C ->A.

The concepts under each of these categories are displayed by default. To hide the details of a category, select the caret symbol next to table name, it toggles between expanding and collapsing the table view. You also have the option of adding concepts to your briefcase to correct any issues.

section.title: Removing concepts from the briefcase
section.para:
There are two options to remove concepts from the Briefcase:
Remove all concepts in the list by selecting the Select All Itemsbutton and then selecting the Remove Selected Items>
To remove one or more concepts but not all concepts from the briefbase select the box to the right of the concept to be removed and select the Remove Selected Items button.

simplesect.title: Refreshing the Briefcase List
simplesect.para: If you do not see the concept(s) just added, try refreshing the list by selecting Refresh List.

section.title: Context Menu
section.para: A context menu appears when users right-click on the concept name either on the taxonomy tree or in the title of concept details panel . Some tables contain a context menu througout the application.

The context menu contains the following options:
Open concept – opens the concept details information
Open concept in new concept viewer – opens the concept details information in a third panel.
Add to briefcase – add the concept to briefcase, which can be viewed in the briefcase tab.
Copy concept, UUID, SCTID, description and SCTID – copies the information described.
Edit concept – opens the concept in edit mode.
Edit concept in new viewer – opens the concept in edit mode, in a third concept details panel.
Clone concept – duplicates the concept information as a new concept.
Clone concept in new viewer – duplicates the concept information as a new concept and opens a new concept details panel.
Create child concept – creates a new child concept with the same information as the selected concept and uses the selected concept as the parent.
Create child concept in new viewer – creates a new child concept with the same information as the selected concept, uses the selected concept as the parent and opens a third concept viewer panel.
Inactivate concept – sets the selected concept's state to inactive. If the concept disappears from the taxonomy, display options are set to not display inactive concepts.
Activate concept – sets the selected concept's state to active. This option is only visible in the context menu if the selected concept is inactive.
